As the latest step toward making the work of the Johns Hopkins
Reserve Officers' Training Corps
battalion as practical as possible,
Professor Tilden announced to the
corps last week that there would
be a course in engineering given
for the benefit of those members
of the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps unit who desire such work.
It is understood that there will
be two courses offered—one will
take up actual field engineering,
such as bridge building and, later,
trench construction; while the
other will give training in surveying and map making. With the
splendid engineering facilities and
the extensive ground at Homewood, Professor Tilden and his
assistants will be able to conduct
the course with a satisfying degree
of completeness. While the course
is not limited to engineering students, it presupposes a working
knowledge of plane geometry and
trigonometry. The classes have
been set tentatively for Tuesday
from 4 to 6 P. M. and Saturday
morning.
In the general orders issued
last week another important step
was taken toward the ultimate
"hundred per cent. efficiency"
which Major Guild has set as the
goal for the Hopkins battalion.
Provision was made for the officers and non-commissioned officers of the battalion to get training in the rank above them. To
this end, the captains will, on
specified occasions, act as battalion commander; the lieutenants
will be given regular opportunities to command their companies;
the adjutant will exchange places
with a company first lieutenant,
and the sergeant-major and the
duty sergeants will have similar
opportunities to learn one another's duties. In this way, the
efficiency of the battalion will be
raised by the fact that whenever
a man is promoted he will be familiar with the duties of his new
station.
In his first lecture for this term,
delivered last Thursday, Major
Guild made it clear that orders
delivered by him "mean business."
He stated that the utter irresponsibility shown by a small group
of men in neglecting to attend
drills and in disregarding orders
has caused him,with the backing of
the University authorities, to es
tablish a system of demerits. Fifty demerits the first semester or
sixty the second will cause a man

The first battalion dance, given
last Friday evening in the lecture
hall of the Civil Engineering
Building, was a brilliant success.
The dance was all that Hopkins
heart could desire; in the words
of a former opponent of the battalion dance plan, it had the "old
cotillions beat a mile."
Every man was in uniform.
Mr. Kistler, the man who has made
these dances possible, remarked to
the writer, "I want to make that
uniform the swellest full-dress outfit that can appear at Hopkins."
The dance was distinctly a battalion dance; civilians were absolutely tabooed. Even the chaperones—Mrs. Guild, Mrs. Abercrombie and Mrs. Kistler—have more
than a passing interest in the
corps.
The battalion dances and the
inter-company athletics are part
of a carefully worked out plan,
originating with Theodore Kistler,
Johns Hopkins physical instructor, and backed by Major Guild
and Dr. Abercrombie, which was
first announced several weeks ago.
While the scheme is expected to
confer many lesser benefits on the
student body, its ultimate goal is
the increased efficiency of the battalion. The dances are expected
to bring out a spirit of battalion
pride and good fellowship among
the men; while the inter-company
athletics are intended to produce
company rivalry, and incidentally
to benefit the men physically. In
Mr. Kistler's own words, "Work
hard and play hard—that's efficiency."
If the enthusiastic co-operation
shown thus far by the students is
any indication, the plan is already
a brilliant success, according to
Mr. Kistler. The three inter-company football games already
staged on Straus Field have been
far from the jokes that many
feared they would be. Right from
the start the brand of football exhibited, while possibly not scientific, has at least been very spirited, and, in the opinion of its backers, it promises big things for the
future.
According to the expressed
opinion of a large number of the
undergraduates, the introduction
of general athletics and a common
social interest is one of the greatest events in the history of the
University.

Saturday battled through a
wretched game of football, characterized by fumbles and rough
and erratic playing on both sides,
to a scoreless tie. The showing of

On Saturday the annual game
with Haverford was played at that
college and for the first time since
relations were established our
eleven came out of the contest undefeated. The game itself was a
slow, deliberate time-consuming
process, for Haverford seemed
bent on conserving her resources
for the Swarthmore game. None
the less she had her usual good
team and was much stronger than
our men had anticipated. Hopkins had not altogether recovered
from the strain of the Western
Maryland game, which, since it
was our first State championship
game, took more of the men than
was generally suspected. It was,
therefore, somewhat natural that
the team should have let down to
some degree, but this letting down
was so marked that it almost resulted in defeat.
The one saving factor of the contest is the fact that the men themselves realize that they did not
play up to the limit of their powers, and this realization makes one
feel that now that the slump is
over better things may be expected. At any rate, better things
must be done if we are to defeat
St. John's. This team from Annapolis is making steady progress
and is, of course, pointing its game
for us, and if we hope to win we
must work for improvement in
several branches of the game.
The team as yet, with the exception of the drive in the Western Maryland game, has not developed a "punch" sufficient to
score on a team like St. John's or
Maryland State. One must remember that a good offense is the
best defense,for the offensive team
possesses all the rights of initiative and all freedom of action. It
is absolutely necessary, therefore,
that this week see a marked development in the power with
which the team carries the ball.
In our interference, likewise, we
must see improvement. In practice, against our own men, the
backs leave their feet and take out
the proper opponent, but it seems
that, once in a contest, the backs
feet are glued to the ground. On
the whole, the line played well at
Haverford, for it more than held
its own, so that, granted normal
growth, its power should be effective in our final games.

When the Johns Hopkins football team, two years ago, succeeded in winning the State.title, the
undergraduates chortled with glee,
Hopkins, they said, had had a successful year in athletics. Twelve
months passed ; a team representing Hopkins was unable to win a
single significant game. The undergraduates were downcast; athletics at Hopkins were rotten.
The funny thing is that in both
cases the real Hopkins was about
the same. One class went out between the years, three remained,
a new class came in which has
proved itself fully up to the standard. Yet one year our athletics
were "fine"; the next, "rotten."
Our physical worth must certainly have been about the same for
both years, good, bad or indifferent, whatever it may really have
been; yet one year we said our
athletics were "fine"; the next
"rotten." Could both estimates
have been true? Isn't it reasonable to suppose that in the average
our standing, whatever it may be,
remains about the same?
. There is something wrong, then,
with our standards of judgment.
If eleven specialists from St.
John's defeat eleven of our specialists on the gridiron, we say

A Tribute.

In looking over the editorial
columns of a NEWS-LETTEROf about
a year ago we find this sentence:
"Hopkins has not awakened; the
spirit which carried our team
through to the winning of the
State championship last year has
been lost; the student body, in the
support of its team, is in a state
of apathy."
For most of us the deplorable condition of affairs at Homewood that brought forth this rebuke is an only too vivid memory.
The situation was a peculiar one.
College traditions and college
spirit must be somehow inseperably bound up with and dependent
upon environment; for when the
Johns Hopkins undergraduates
were lifted bodily from their old
quarters to the beautiful new ones
at Homewood, these invaluable attributes seemed to be utterly lost.
The general attitude toward football and college activity generally,
was a sort of tolerant apathy,
maddening to those who had
worked so hard for the building
up of Hopkins traditions and
Hopkins spirit. The students—I
am speaking of the great majority
—came and went with regard only
to what Hopkins could give them.
Nothing was further from their
thoughts than that they either
could or should give Hopkins anything in return.
It remained for a few determined spirits like the writer of the
paragraph I have quoted, to call
us to order, to revivify and cause
to grow in our hearts that spirit
which has made and shall make
the name of Johns Hopkins glorious. We can never be sufficiently
thankful to these men. As we grow
and prosper let us not forget the
men who made that growth and
prosperity possible.

To the Editor

Sir—There has been much discussion lately about the campaign
for the relief of prisoners of war.
It has been said that the money
would go to German prisoners in
allied camps, and that any money
reaching Germany would be appropriated by the German government.
It is contrary to the true idea
of the war, and also very smallminded, to consider the German
Prisoners unworthy of relief. We
are fighting their government, not
them. They will have no further
part in the war ; hence, if they are
helped it will not advance the
(;erman cause, but rather our own.
by proving to them our good
wishes. By this means only we
may enable the V. M. C. A. to
reach our soldiers imprisoned in
(;ermany.
These allied prisoners, being
idle, need more of our attention
than the soldiers in the trenches.
Let us give those conducting the
campaign credit for a little common sense. If our money meant
for the allied prisoners were unlikely to reach its'destination, it is
very improbable that such an organization as the Y. M. C. A.
would risk it when it is so much
needed elsewhere. We may be
sure the money will be well used.
The need is great; we must stop
talking and give.

year from now. Germany is the

When the Johns Hopkins football team, two years ago, succeeded in winning the State.title, the
undergraduates chortled with glee,
Hopkins, they said, had had a successful year in athletics. Twelve
months passed ; a team representing Hopkins was unable to win a
single significant game. The undergraduates were downcast; athletics at Hopkins were rotten.
The funny thing is that in both
cases the real Hopkins was about
the same. One class went out between the years, three remained,
a new class came in which has
proved itself fully up to the standard. Yet one year our athletics
were "fine"; the next, "rotten."
Our physical worth must certainly have been about the same for
both years, good, bad or indifferent, whatever it may really have
been; yet one year we said our
athletics were "fine"; the next
"rotten." Could both estimates
have been true? Isn't it reasonable to suppose that in the average
our standing, whatever it may be,
remains about the same?
. There is something wrong, then,
with our standards of judgment.
If eleven specialists from St.
John's defeat eleven of our specialists on the gridiron, we say
that athletics at Hopkins are in
a fearful state; and, moreover,
that St. John's is our superior in
athletics. But what are we judging from? The athletic performance of less than five per cent, of
our number, if we allow for all
substitutions. That's science for
you!

A Tribute.

In looking over the editorial
columns of a NEWS-LETTEROf about
a year ago we find this sentence:
"Hopkins has not awakened; the
spirit which carried our team
through to the winning of the
State championship last year has
been lost; the student body, in the
support of its team, is in a state
of apathy."
For most of us the deplorable condition of affairs at Homewood that brought forth this rebuke is an only too vivid memory.
The situation was a peculiar one.
College traditions and college
spirit must be somehow inseperably bound up with and dependent
upon environment; for when the
Johns Hopkins undergraduates
were lifted bodily from their old
quarters to the beautiful new ones
at Homewood, these invaluable attributes seemed to be utterly lost.
The general attitude toward football and college activity generally,
was a sort of tolerant apathy,
maddening to those who had
worked so hard for the building
up of Hopkins traditions and
Hopkins spirit. The students—I
am speaking of the great majority
—came and went with regard only
to what Hopkins could give them.
Nothing was further from their
thoughts than that they either
could or should give Hopkins anything in return.
It remained for a few determined spirits like the writer of the
paragraph I have quoted, to call
us to order, to revivify and cause
to grow in our hearts that spirit
which has made and shall make
the name of Johns Hopkins glorious. We can never be sufficiently
thankful to these men. As we grow
and prosper let us not forget the
men who made that growth and
prosperity possible.

Sir—There has been much discussion lately about the campaign
for the relief of prisoners of war.
It has been said that the money
would go to German prisoners in
allied camps, and that any money
reaching Germany would be appropriated by the German government.
It is contrary to the true idea
of the war, and also very smallminded, to consider the German
Prisoners unworthy of relief. We
are fighting their government, not
them. They will have no further
part in the war ; hence, if they are
helped it will not advance the
(;erman cause, but rather our own.
by proving to them our good
wishes. By this means only we

reach our soldiers imprisoned in
(;ermany.
These allied prisoners, being
idle, need more of our attention
than the soldiers in the trenches.
Let us give those conducting the
campaign credit for a little common sense. If our money meant
for the allied prisoners were unlikely to reach its'destination, it is
very improbable that such an organization as the Y. M. C. A.
would risk it when it is so much
needed elsewhere. We may be
sure the money will be well used.
The need is great; we must stop
talking and give.
